poem:
Title: "An Elegy for a Tongue Unhushed"

Mourning whispers through Hebridean islands,
where Gaelic ghosts roam unfettered,
their silent cries echo in half-lit corridors,
while translucent words flutter like moths,
against the dim lantern of progress.

This tale of a furred tongue, unlicked and battered,
gagged by modernity's cruel hand,
makes the dram bitter, the ceilidh quiet.
But no Scot, can un-Hear the whispers, 
of his own haunted homeland.
